Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2011 02:32PM profbee wrote: Hi, Dina.  I'm so sorry that you're going through that.  I think I have 540 ccs....and I did that in like 2 fills after the initial fill at my BMX.  I never had any pain..a little tightness for a day or so...and kind of uncomfortable, but not pain.  I just got measured for a bra at Vicky's Secret and they said 38D.  I'm 5' 10" and like 160 lbs.  I'm kind of in between C & D.  I think it's hard to get an exact cup size before...you could still be in between after the surgery I mean.  BUT.. My plastic surgeon was moving from one hospital to another.  I had trouble getting an appt for my surgery.  So finally, I called  my breast surgeon (who did the first half of my mastectomy) and said I need a referral for another surgeon since I can't get an appt with my plastic surgeon.  They set me up with someone else...and then lo and behold my plastic surgeon called me himself an hour later and set aside a surgery date for me.  :)  If you're not happy with this guy, I would totally get a recommendation for someone else. They don't need to hear all about WHY you want someone else (docs do tend to protect each other)...I would just say I'd just rather have another surgeon.   Oh, and I think cleavage is like really hard to get with the implants, but maybe I'm wrong.  I don't know...these TEs are pretty darn big on me, but I've always had a space between my boobs.  I can't imagine how big they'd have to be to get cleavage!  Scary!! Good luck.  i'm sorry this has been so tough.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2011 06:38PM profbee wrote: Sorry you're dealing with this.  I was Stage 2 IDC, but I had the option for lumpectomy.  I went with a BMX--same as above--fear that it would recur, being under 40 as well with a small child and a career (and a great hubby!) also made me choose being aggressive about treatment at every turn.  BUT...I want to say that a BMX is not a walk in the park.  You don't wind up with implant boobs--unless you do nipple-sparing (I was not a candidate), you have no nipples, big scars right across your breasts, and months of expansion (which can be just tightness, but some say pain), followed by another surgery for exchange.  And then you have to wait months more for them to do somthing that will approximate a nipple and tattoo an areola on.  This is my experience anyway.   I am usually a really UP person, I don't mean to be a downer but I had a friend recently say she was so jealous that I was getting stripper boobs that would always stay up.  I know she meant well, but I was like you don't want THESE, and I just wanted to say what no one said to me.  I mean, I STILL would have chosen the BMX, but I think I had really unrealistic ideas about what my end result would be.  The fear of recurrence was too much for me, and I am glad that I picked a BMX rather than lumpectomy with radiation (I had to have chemo either way). Best of luck.  Take your time to make this decision.  It's a toughie.
Posts.Title: Such heavy decisions... katiebug msphil

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 03:39PM profbee wrote: Sorry you're about to start in on this.  I have to say, though, that I wasn't as upset by the hair loss as I thought I'd be.  I had long hair.  I went to the shop...they put 6 ponytails all over my head, cut them off and left me with a really short pretty cute hairdo.  I then donated those ponytails for children's wigs.  :)  That made me feel good about it, and reminded me how much harder this is on some.  For me, it is temporary my hair will (and is now) grow(ing) back.   I have 2 women friends with alopecia.  And when I wanted to get upset about it, I kept reminding myself that this is temporary for me.   When my hair did start coming out it was really annoying.  Not clumps so much for me, but if I was reading a book, put my hand through my hair, there would be hair all over the book.  I could just tug it gently right out.  So, I wanted it gone.  Hubby shaved it for me with the help of my little 5 year old son.  I laughed through it.  I think it was toughest on my hubby.  That said, I don't think you really look obviously like you're going through treatment until you lose your eyebrows.  For me, that was after I lost my hair.   I also got a wig.  I barely wore it, but there were a few days (son's birthday, a friend's wedding) when I was so glad I had it.  It cheered hubby and son to see my looking like my old self, but I found it uncomfortable and didn't wear it often.  There are a few sites that send free head scarves to women in cancer treatment...France Luxe the Good Wishes Program is one.  Oh gosh the other one is not coming to me.  Anyway, they are gorgeous silk head wraps.  It felt so good to have something ready to turn to when I didn't have any hair.  Oh, and...it gets CHILLY fast, so you need to have some hats around.   One of the best things...I bought some new shoes!  :)  A dear friend sent me a zappos gift certificate.  Fun, fun, fun, and helped me not focus on my head.  You'll be alright.  You can do this.  Best of luck!!!

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2012 04:47PM profbee wrote: Leelee...you've heard it here, but I wanted to add one more voice to the chorus.  :)  You said that you think a huge reason you are so afraid is you have waited so long.  So, let's stop that and find out what's going on.  When I'm approaching a scan or test that makes me nervous I remind myself...listen, it's not that you are waiting for the axe to fall.  Whatever you learn already IS.  You're just gaining knowledge of it--all the better to treat it and get rid of it if it is something...and it is highly likely that it is not something serious.  Remember, here, you're pretty much talking to breast cancer survivors.  There are way more people out there who have little bumps and whatnot that don't have breast cancer.  So, find out what it is.  It'll likely be nada and you can move on from the stress of worry.  I'm a mom too, and I know we often put ourselves last, but this past year I learned that it is because of my son that I have to take care of ME first.  If I'm not here, then what?  (There's a reason why on a plane you put your own oxygen mask on first!)  So, do this for you and your kids.   You can do it.   And we're here to support you through it.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 07:08PM profbee wrote: Oh gosh!  When it rains, it pours, eh?  I'm so sorry!  I don't have much advice for you...except to say that my real weight bearing problems were with raising my arms, but maybe you could talk to a physical therapist who has experience with mastectomy patients to see what they'd say before your surgery.  Is there any way you can set up camp somewhere in the house (like make up a place to sleep in the living room) so you could avoid some stairs for a while?  I felt better pretty fast after my BMX.  It might be worth it for a few days.  AND...I'd stay in the hospital for a few days where they can take care of you.  Depending on how your surgery goes, you can go home pretty quickly.  I stayed 2 nights, and I think it really helped me have help to get up, walk around a bit, etc.   Best of luck!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 06:55PM profbee wrote: I went in to mammogram my lump.  The tech said I had dense breasts and needed an ultrasound.  They stopped being really nice and were suddenly very professional and distant.  The radiologist came in and flat out said, "I'm really worried."  Yeah.  Me too.  That was a Friday.  They got me an appt with a surgeon for the following Monday.  I knew.  The doc looked at me and said, "You probably have cancer."  He wanted to book a lumpectomy right then and there.  (I went alone...might as well...I knew already.)  I made him do a needle biopsy then and there because I needed to KNOW 100% before I went ahead with anything else.  He asked if I would like to come in for the results and I said, "Doc, we both know I have cancer.  So, all you're going to tell me is how bad it is.  We can do that over the phone."  So, he called a few days later with the dx.   That's when we went with a second opinion down to Boston to Dana Farber and I got on a clinical trial.   I was anxious to move ahead, but in the end it was so much better for me that we waited and got a second opinion.

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2012 09:53AM profbee wrote: What KIND of breast cancer is it?  (ILC--invasive lobular carcinoma or IDC--invasive ductal carcinoma or mucineous)  Most are IDC.  Oooh...or even DCIS. Ask what the results are for ER and PR (estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor--it will indicate which chemo meds will work for you) Ask if you are HER2 positive (this is a protein that also changes your treatment plan--this test takes a few days, so often you don't hear this at the initial diagnosis)  These next things can change as they go, for instance they can think it's 2 cm and get in there and it's really just 1. How large is the lump?  Are there any signs of invasion?   You could ask what stage she thinks you'd be (again, this can change and he may not be able to answer, but you may want to know what she thinks) Ask her what she thinks the next steps should be (surgery, chemo, radiation, etc.)--but I would recommend getting a second opinion before you go ahead with anything anyway.   Ask her what you should do now.  (Call a breast surgeon?)  Specifically, is there more testing that we should do now to get a complete picture (MRI? Another biopsy?)? I'm sure others will chime in, and I'd bet there's a list over on BC.org somewhere.  :)

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2012 12:28PM profbee wrote: Up in NH I saw a nice retiring (in just a few months) doc who wanted to do a lumpectomy right away.  I wound up putting the brakes on, and I went down to Boston.  It's over an hour drive, but in morning traffic, closer to 2.  We always gave ourselves lots of time and just went EARLY.  But, I got on a clinical trial, watched my tumor shrink, had a complete pathological response (no sign of cancer) at surgery time, and then did more chemo to do the standard of care.  Long story short--I believe I got WAY better care.  That said, when it came time for a year of Herceptin treatments once every 3 weeks, I decided to do that at my local hospital.  So, I still go down and see my onc in Boston, but only every few months or so--and it will be fewer and farther between soon.  :)   I didn't need rads because I did the mastectomy.  Early on, I think it's just totally worth it to at least hear a second opinion.  BEST of luck, Hap!

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2012 09:33PM profbee wrote: Think about your audience.  So, who are they?  What do you think would be an interesting topic to them?  I'd give some of the overwhelming statistics, but not too many.  Ooooh....you could start out asking them to write down the names of the first 8 women in their life they think of.  Then get into the stats.  I'd also take this opportunity to tell them to feel their boobs!!!  I once talked to a class about HPV and got an email years later thanking me because one student indeed had cervical cancer, so I would use my time.   When I started out this semester I first addressed why I was bald and how you need to know your breasts and know your body (men and women) and encourage the women in your lives to go to the doctor, etc.   Another thing I find stuns people is about the "caught it early" so it's curable myth.  To open students' eyes about this misconception would be really informative too. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2012 01:36PM profbee wrote: Totally doesn't sound strange to me!   How can you possibly know how you'll feel?  You've never been here before!  You can see from my signature, that I'm done with the tough stuff (still doing the Herceptin infusions once every 3 weeks and the Tamoxifen pill every day), but I still sometimes stop and think, "What the hell was THAT?!  Did this last year just happen?!"   May I say another thing or two.  One, if you take the pain meds, get some stool softener.  I swear, the constipation is worse than the pain.  Really.  Second, it is weird to wake up without a breast or two.  It is weird to look in the mirror and see scarred Barbie nipple-free boobs.  I hadn't really anticipated that.  I mean, I knew it was going to happen, but yeah, it was definitely something to get used to.  And that's alright.  But, third, and finally, you'll be so surprised by how much you can do this.  I hope that doesn't sound as corny as I fear.  But, really, if you told me I'd have to go through all this, I would have said no thank you.  Every single step...and I'm not saying they were easy...was easier than I feared.  You'll do it.  You'll get through.  You have to.   Good luck, Sharon!
